div1.p: A biographical sketch, with corrections [by Laura Armistead Carter?], describes H.R. Carter's family, education, career, and character.

div1.p:
Carter, Henry Rose, physician, was born at Clifton
Plantation, Caroline County. Va., Aug. 25, 1852, son of Henry Rose and Emma
Caroline (Coleman) Carter. John Carter, his earliest American ancestor, came
over from Garston Manor. Hertfordshire, England, in 1649, settling at Coroto-
man, Lancaster County, Va. and the line of descent from him and his wife,
Sarah Ludlowe, is through their son Robert Carter (q. v.) and his wife Judith
Armistead; John and Elizabeth Hill; Edward and Sarah (Champe); and Hill and
Mary (Rose) who were Dr. Carter's grandparents. His father was U. S. com-
missioner to the Indians and an early settler of Mississippi. The son was
graduated with the degree of C. E. at the University of Virginia in 1873,
and returned there for one year as Assistant in Applied Mathematics. His
medical degree was received at the College of Medicine of the University of
Maryland in 1879. He began the practice of medicine at Baltimore, Md. in
partnership with Dr. Frank West, but soon entered the Marine Hospital Ser-
vice of the United States as Assistant Surgeon. In 1888 he was sent to
Ship Island quarantine station in the Gulf of Mexico, where he began the
study of yellow fever, in the control and prevention of which he became a
world authority. There were at that time no uniform regulations for quar-
antine at American ports, or reliable data upon which to base them. Dr.
Carter deduced the fact that six days covered the maximum period of incu-
bation in man and counted this period from the completion of disinfection
of the vessel. He was promoted to the rank of passed assistant surgeon
in 1882, of surgeon in 1892 and senior surgeon in 1912. On March 4, 1915
he was made assistant surgeon general by special act of Congress. In the
last decade of the nineteenth century, he was sent to various points in
Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana and other Southern States to combat epidemics

epidemics of yellow fever and contracted the disease himself. His work at
McHenry, Miss., in 1898 resulted in the first suppression of a yellow fever
epidemic in the South in the summer time. In 1899 he was made chief quaran-
tine officer of Cuba and in 1904 was detailed for duty at Panama, at both
places inaugurating the quarantine service. He was also director of hospi-
tals at Panama and remained there five years. In 1913 he conducted the first
successful campaign for the control of malaria made in the United States,
and from then, until his retirement in 1919, he was engaged in combatting
malaria in the South. During the World War, he inaugurated control measures
for malaria in the extra-cantonment areas of the camps and in the regions
around the large industrial plants engaged in the production of war material.
He was sanitary advisor to the Peruvian Government in 1920-and= 21 and a
member of the yellow fever commission of the Rockefeller Foundation 1915-25.
He was author of nearly forty papers published in public health reports and
medical journals, sections on yellow fever in “The Practice of Medicine in
the Tropics,” Abt's “System of Pediatrics” and the "Nelson Loose Leaf Medi-
cine. His various intellectual interests included mathematics, ethnology,
languages and literature, with a special fondness for poetry. Steadfast-
ness of purpose, unlimited endurance and enthusiasm in the service of
humanity were his dominating characteristics. He was a member of the
National Malaria Committee of which he was secretary and honorary president;
The American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, andbut the Canal Zone
Medical Society, and fellow of the Royal Society of tracks-feed. & Hygiene and of the Academy of Medicine, Caracas, Venezuela. He
was married, Sept. 29, 1880, to Laura Eugenia, daughter of Henry Hook of
Belleville, Ill., by whom he had three children, Henry Rose, a physician,
Edward Champe, an author and musician, and Laura Armistead Carter, who as-
sisted her father in his scientific work. He died in Washington, D. C.,
September 14, 1925.
